RNAscope® in situ hybridization followed by immunohistochemistry revealed that 79% of neurons express CCL5 mRNA in this region. microglia, astrocytes, and few oligodendrocytes also express CCL5 mRNA in 11.4%, 13.7% and 5.9% respectively. our results reveal a unique expression profile of CCL5 mRNA throughout the adult rodent brain. we found that the cellular anatomical distribution of this chemokine is highly regionalized and restricted to certain parts of the brain. a constitutive expression of CCL5 mRNA was also present in some subset of neuronal cell in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus. mRNA is constitutively expressed in all glial cells (microglia, astrocytes and oligodendrocytes) as well as in a subset of neurons. the fact that CCL5 proteins are detected in the adult brain supports the notion that CCL5 might have a role as potential modulators of brain function. oligodendrocyte precursors or other glial cells might be regulating their own proliferation via the release of CCL5. oligodendrocytes maintain axonal integrity, support axonal metabolism and aid neuronal survival. CCL5 is not the only chemokine that is expressed in neurons.
